I don't know the answer to this, but this video causes me to question body dysmorphia and body acceptance. Being overweight and having poor cardiovascular health are major contraindications to living a healthy and full life. Body dysmorphia is real, and sections of the population DO suffer from it and need to comprehend a broader perspective of health and wellness and what it means to live a full life. But this video seems to suggest that if you're overweight, you're okay...This is wrong. You CAN be okay if you're overweight, but you should strive to live the fullest life possible with the least medical complications and medical bills. Strive to eat well and exercise regularly. It's not shameful to not workout, but you're doing yourself a favor by taking some time out of your day/week to get some exercise in and to eat a calorically and micronutriently stable died . You'll live longer, you'll have more energy...Idk, just do yourself a favor...

Honestly, I have never thought "I am ugly." After looking at some thin model. Know what messed up my body image? That dann teacher in 1st grade that wanted to send me home because "You're looking sick." I wasn't sick. It was just how I looked. About the age 12 I started to wear super heavy make up to hide my pale skin because I was afraid of looking sick. It took me years to understand that I don't need to do that in order to look healthy. People just have to come to terms with me being very pale. I felt that my knees were ugly for years because some PE teacher asked if I am alright because he thought that my knees looked weird somehow. I still feel uncomfortable wearing pants with holes or shorts. And I had the same thing with so many other things about my body. But mostly those comments were made by people I trusted. Like doctors, friends and teachers. Yes, even teachers who asked my father if I am suffering from an eating dissorder because they felt like I was too thin. I didn't suffer from an eating dissorder. I am just a naturally thin person.

Social Media and TV and stuff can be super bad for your body image. But it's not the only thing and sadly most studies only focus on that because it is easier to blame some Model instead of looking at the people around you.

Another thing: since my mother is a psychatrist, I never really got to watch TV shows with unrealistic body images and I wasn't really allowed to play with Barbie and whatever. She considered it to be bad for my body image. So most of those factors weren't as present in my life, especially during the first few years. And I still had some major problems about my body. And as I said, mostly because of comments from people whom I trusted and as a child looked up to. And not bad or mean comments either. Those people were usually worried. But if your teacher asks your parents if you're sick because you look different, it makes you feel like absolut shit. So people should seriously start to consider that and maybe just stop judging kids for how they look. If you feel like someone may look a little sick, stop saying "You look sick." Just ask "How are you?" Because chances are that the person always looks like that.
